  When San Diego noise-pop duo Brandon Welchez and Charles Rowell released their attitude-laden debut Summer of Hate in 2009, many people highlighted the schizophrenic nature of their sound. On the Berlin-recorded Endless Flowers, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s hard not to feel that the circles on Welchez and RowellÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s thematic Venn diagram have been forced together this time around to produce maximum overlap. This self-produced offering has a sunnier disposition than its predecessors, and the recurrent "flower" motif - symbolic of love, death and fragile beauty - provides the album with lyrical focus and continuity. Crucially, their bold decision to expand to a five-piece also delivers sonic cohesion, allowing one propulsive, hook-filled tune to bleed seamlessly into the next. Recalling the Cure at their most carefree, both the bittersweet Ã¢â‚¬Å“Endless FlowersÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and the crunching slice of power pop that is Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sunday (Psychic Conversation #9),Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ are the kind of euphoric set-openers designed to deliver broad appeal. Pleasingly, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a guise that fits them as perfectly as their sunglasses.
